Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamics and Predictability of East and Central Pacific El Ni√±o/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) Events
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impacts of this collaborative project include furthering understanding of different types of El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events and their predictability, and the training of two graduate students, This project will further our understanding of the dynamics and predictability of Central Pacific and East Pacific ENSO events. The research team has extensive experience in using observational constrained approaches as well as in undertaking simulations using a suite of physical models.

The following scientific questions will be addressed: What dynamical processes are responsible for the evolution of initial structures into a particular type of ENSO event? Are there physical mechanisms that can explain the stochastic forcing of these initial structures? How do initial structures and stochastic forcing throughout the evolution of a particular event affect the predictability of a particular type of ENSO event? How important - and how predictable - are changes in mean state conditions versus changes in stochastic forcing in influencing long-term variations in the statistics of different types of ENSO events?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:This project has furthered our understanding of the dynamics and predictability of Central Pacific (CP) and East Pacific (EP) El Niño / Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events. ENSO events differ from each other in spatial structure and in temporal evolution. This project used a variety of different models with differing complexity to understand these variations, ranging from simple theoretical models, to empirically derived models, to full general circulation models. Results characterize and quantify the effect of structures in initial states, and in temporally varying “stochastic” forcing, that lead to CP and EP ENSO events.

 

In addition to understanding spatial structures and temporal evolution of ENSO events with differing characteristics, this project quantified the predictable and non-predictable components of these variations through use of empirically derived linear inverse models. Further, the project developed a technique to characterize “state dependent noise” (stochastic variations that both depend on how ENSO is evolving, and ultimately influence its evolution) within the empirical models. This technique has immense promise in characterizing and simulating variability in our climate system. 

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this project is that it combines observationally constrained Linear Inverse Models (LIMs), designed experiments using full-physics climate models, and theoretical analyses. The LIMs provide estimates of the dynamics of CP and EP variability that are constrained by observations, but the LIMs are limited in their ability to explore specific physical processes. The designed model experiments are complimentary to the LIM analyses in that they allow detailed exploration of very specific physical processes but must be compared with the observational analyses in order to ensure relevancy in the natural world. By using a wide range of tools, we better understand and characterize why ENSO events develop with differing spatial and temporal characteristics. 

Broader Impacts:The broader impacts of this work include its societal contribution through furthering our understanding of different types of ENSO events and their predictability, training of three Ph.D. graduate students, contributions to US CLIVAR research and discussions, contributions to ongoing efforts at ENSO prediction at NOAA ESRL, and hosting a session on ENSO prediction at a national conference. We note that the Ph.D. students spent time at UW-Madison and at NOAA ESRL, which contributes to student training by exposing the students to a broad range of research activities at both institutions.
